blocks.text: The Saratoga battle grounds north of Albany, where Americans decisively defeated the British in 1777, marking the turning point of the American Revolution and a decisive battle in world history.

blocks.text: Benedict Arnold was the hero of the battle of Saratoga, and received a serious leg wound. This unique monument has been erected to Arnold's wounded leg. If he had been killed in the battle, his name would be today enshrined in the annals of American history.
STOP NO. 4
A victory monument at Schuylersville (Old Saratoga).
It's been a full day today, but no one appears tired when we located two cabins for the night just south of Hudson Falls ($14). Contax wide open at f1.5, 1/2 sec.

blocks.text: SECOND DAY: Saturday, August 28 - Glens Falls to Lake George, enter Vermont north of Ticonderoga, to Burlington, east through Green Mountains to Montpelier, into New Hampshire, through section of White Mountains to (near) Bartlett, N. H. for night. 7:55 A.M. to 7:40 P.M. - total 602 miles.
At Burlington, Vt., a view of Lake Champlain with the Adirondacks visible in the distance. With the Adirondack dams visible in the distance.
First stop in Vermont for refreshments after crossing a narrow neck of Lake Champlain. A sunny day, more than we had hoped.

blocks.text:
Eastward now through the beautiful Green Mount-
ains of Vermont. We forego a trip to the top of
Mt. Mansfield, highest point in the state.
Lunch at this small roadside restaurant in the heart of the Green Mountains. The owners are obviously of French descent.

blocks.text: An interesting visit to the Rock of Ages quarry near Barre. This is one of the oldest monumental granite quarries in the world, is the world's largest granite quarry with a depth equal to the height of a 27-story building.
ROCK OF AGES BARRE VER
The Capit ool of Vermont at Mont-pelier has a gilded dome sur-mounted by a statue of Ceres.

blocks.text: Rough granite has been removed by drilling.
Of all things to add to an already overloaded car - specimens of granite.

In New Hampshire after crossing the Connec-ticut River at Woodsville this covered bridge a short distance beyond the state line. The road is so rough the car develops a "wiggle" which persists to the end of the trip.

At North Woodstock, N. H., we join the main north-south route through the White Mountains. Tourists get special attention: witness a bear on a pole who feeds himself by means of a pulley attached to a cup which is filled by visitors from an automatic vending machine, and an ancient logging locomotive displayed along-side a curio shop.

blocks.text: The Old Man of the Mountain maintains his lonely vigil as he did when he inspired Hawthorne to write "The Great Stone Face".

Shadows are lengthening as we approach Fran-
conia Notch, probably the most interesting
of all the notches in New Hampshire.
The children tussle for a telescopic view of the aerial tramway up the side of Cannon Mountain.

blocks.text: The most fabulous of all the White Mountain resorts, the Mt. Washington Hotel, scene of the 1944 U. N. Monetary and Financial Conference. In the background is the Presidential Range, with Mt. Washington (extreme right) being nudged by a cloud, the highest point in New England at 6,288 feet.

THIRD DAY: Sunday, August 29 - Bartlett, N. H. to Maine line at Fryeburg, by-pass Portland to Route #1, to Brunswick, Bath and Damariscotta. 7:20 A. M. to Noon.
133 miles – total 735 miles.
Breakfast at the "Old Colony" restaurant in North Conway, the same restaurant where we had dinner with the Hubbers in June of 1951.
This cottage along the Saco River provided ample room for seven.
We discover our second covered bridge over the Saco River just before leaving New Hamp-shire.

Maine, at last, where we enter the attractive town of Fryeburg.

blocks.text: Brunswick is best known as the home of Bowdoin College, but there are many statelyly well preserved old homes. Here Harriet Beecher Stowe wrote Uncle Tom's Cabin her home is shown above at right.
The town for which we have been looking, main street of Damariscotta, reached about noon.
A brief stop at the information office for a map of the region...then five miles through the woods to our cottage on Pemaquid Pond.

blocks.text: From Noon, Sunday, August 29 to morning of Saturday, September 4, spent at cottage on Pemaquid Pond on peninsula south of Damariscotta, Maine. Various trips from cottage total 516 miles.
We occupy "Sandy Beach", the same cottage we occupied in mid-August of 1949.
It's a tranquil existence, given over to loafing, reading, swimming and boating.

blocks.text: Our quiet life is disrupted on Tuesday, August 31, when we are lashed by the tail of hurricane 'Carol' which veers inland from the Atlantic killing 50 to 60 people in the Boston-Providence area. A number of trees go down around us and limbs are shorn off. We go to bed Tuesday night with the wind howling and not knowing when a tree might crash our cottage. Luckily, we escaped untouched.
The hurrriicccanne klooks out both our elecceecccriccccciiiittty and our water supply for the duration of our stay at Pemaquid.
Our placid pond looks like a miniature ocean at the height of the hurricane.
Below - the next morning the children examine the damage.

Our quiet life is disrupted on Tuesday, August 31, when we are lashed by the tail of hurricane 'Carol' which veers inland from the Atlantic killing 50 to 60 people in the Boston-Providence area. A number of trees go down around us and limbs are shorn off. We go to bed Tuesday night with the wind howling and not knowing when a tree might crash our cottage. Luckily, we escaped untouched.

The hurrriicccanne klooks out both our elecceecccriccccciiiittty and our water supply for the duration of our stay at Pemaquid.

Our placid pond looks like a miniature ocean at the height of the hurricane.

Below - the next morning the children examine the damage.

M.) - Gordon and Kitty take a 296 miles trip to Mount Desert Island which includes Bar Harbor, Cadillac Mountain and a large part of Acadia National Park. Discovered and named by Champlain in 1604, the Island was granted to Antoine de la Mothe Cadillac by Louis XIV.
Suspension bridge across the mouth of the Penobscot River (now toll free).
The public fishing wharf and sightseeing boats at Bar Harbor. Few people in the town indicate the main season is past.

Northeast Harbor Harbborough; another yachting port where many wealthy summer visitors reside.

blocks.text: Cadillac Mountain on Mount Desert Island is the highest point on the entire Atlantic coast of the United States (1,532 ft.).
This trip is Gordon's and Kitty's fourth trip to the top, one time in fog.
The road to the top was constructed in 1931.
Beyond Kitty's head is Bar Harbor, with the Porcupine Islands in Frenchman's Bay.

blocks.text: NINTH DAY: Saturday, September 4 – Leave for home from Damariscotta, Maine, to Portland, on Maine Turnpike to Kennebunk, along coast to Portsmouth, N. H., inland to Manchester, enter Mass. to Fitchburg, to Athol, to Holyoke, enter Conn. to (near) Farmington for night. 8:15 A. M. to 10:00 P. M. 320 miles.
The children are ready to admit everything will not fit into the car for the trip home.
Our main reason for visiting Kennebunk, to see the Wedding Cake House, which, so the story goes, was built by a local swain to give his bride something different.

blocks.text: Cindy and Louise give the 1950 Chrysler Imperial a final cleaning. Purchased in December, 1950 the speedometer discloses we have driven it more than 117M miles in slightly more than four years, four months.
On April 16 we purchase a 1955 Chrysler New Yorker Deluxe St. Regis hardtop model in two tones of red and sand, with a 250 hp motor. The girls give their enthusiastic approval.

blocks.text: April 21 - 24, 1955. Gordon and Harold Reece make a business trip to Charleston, W. Va. to visit the district office of Educators Mutual Insurance Company; with Gordon adding a side trip to Ashland, Ky. to attend the charter dinner of the Ashland Chapter of American Business Clubs. Lancaster to Charleston on 472 miles; Charleston to Ashland and return 140 miles; Charleston to Lancaster 525 miles; total trip 1,137 miles. New Chrysler.
The imposing capitol of West Virginia in Charleston on the banks of the Kanawha.

blocks.text: We explore twenty five miles of the recently opened, multi-million dollar West Virginia Turnpike which runs south from Charleston. We agree it is the most spectacular of all the turnpikes, but lack of sufficient traffic volume may lead to financial difficulties in paying off the bonded indebtedness.

blocks.text: Through the mountains...
With many hairpin curves.
As we head north through the mountains for Berkeley Springs we encounter a severe thunder storm which impedes our progress so that we arrive home well after midnight.
Heavy rock overhang on the road to Petersburg.
End - Trip to W. Va. & Ky.

blocks.text: Picnic time...
May 7 - Louise enters her friends.
Conestoga ABC holds a Bar-B-Q, with all the Landreaths in attendance. Shown are Bauman, Gallagher and Truxal.
Lancaster ABC's annual lobster fiesta features live lobsters direct from Maine. Cris Herr is chief cook.
The girls spend a relaxing Sunday afternoon in the back yard.

blocks.text: May 29, 30, 30, 1955 (Memorial Day week end) - A trip to the mountains of West Virginia and Virginia with John and Louise Davis. First day: 448 miles to Harrisonburg, Va; second day: home via Skyline Drive, 262 miles; total trip, 710 miles. Chrysler.
Entrance to Blackwater Falls State Park four miles southwest of Davis, W. Va.
The Blackwater River takes a 63 foot tum-ble. Boys are diving through the Falls.
Path to the Falls.

blocks.text: The gorge formed by the Blackwater River is almost 1,000 feet deep in places.
The views from Bickle Knob, 4,008 ft., are largely obscured by rain when we reach the top. Bickle Knob is east of Elkins; it is reached on Stuart Memorial Drive.
It is always a pleasure to view Germany Valley, outstanding in the East.

blocks.text: Heavy rainfall accompanies us across the mountains to Harrisonburg, Va. where we spend the night at the Pure Village, four miles south of the town.
The sun is shining again when we rise the morning of the second day and breakfast.
East of Harrisonburg we climb to the Skyline Drive, which we follow north to Front Royal. It is a beautiful day with just enough coolness to require light jackets.

blocks.text: Gordon and Kitty attend the National Convention of American Business Clubs in Allentown, Pa., June 23 - 25, as well as the pre-Convention party with the children at Reading, Pa.

Past National Presidents of A. B. C. attending the Allenentown Convention; L to R.
(standing): F. H. Bachman (Champaign, Ill.); Preston L. Johnston (Lubbock, Texas);
Charles E. Mitchell (Detroit, Mich.); Jim Lovelace (High Point, N. C.); Gordon
(Lancaster, Pa.); William C. Kirchheim (Augusta, Ga.); Paul D. Fossett (Enid, Okla.)
L. to R. (seated): George W. Hansen (Muskegon, Mich.); Harold C. Blankenberger

New National Officers of American Business Clubs elected at Allentown:
President -- William C. Eyke, Muskegon, Mich.
National First Vice-President -- Joseph F. Prola, Springfield, Ill.

blocks.text: July 6, 1955 - The Landreth girls with Tamara Thomas and Carole Nolt hold their 5th Annual Talent Show for Heart Haven in Landreth's back yard. A record crowd of approximately 150 men, women and children spread out into two neighboring back yards. When the show is over the girls present $73 to Heart Haven as proceeds from the collection at intermission. Everybody is enthused.
Gordon has printed about 200 circulars for distribution.
The Lancaster New Era is generous with newspaper space giving the show a four column spread. Shown above are cindy, Tamaara, Carole, Louise, Nancy and Kathy.

blocks.text: July, 1954, was not only the hottest July, but the hottest of all months on record in Lancaster County. Daytime temperatures reached 90 or higher degrees on 25 days (and we thought 19 days of 90 or higher degrees on 25 days Official rainfall was only .54 inch, lowest since records were started in 1899 Average humidity was over 50 per cent on all but a few days, and rose as high as 81 per cent.
The next book begins with the Landreth family's trip to Florida in August.

pages.full_text:
July, 1954, was not only the hottest July, but the hottest of all months on record in Lancaster County. Daytime temperatures reached 90 or higher degrees on 25 days (and we thought 19 days of 90 or higher degrees on 25 days Official rainfall was only .54 inch, lowest since records were started in 1899 Average humidity was over 50 per cent on all but a few days, and rose as high as 81 per cent.

The next book begins with the Landreth family's trip to Florida in August.
